item.title: College Pandtimemic
item.description: During Pandemic I wrote the following during the pandemic, in the summer of 2020. _College graduation is supposed to be a landmark time. Pandemic’s are too. Having both at the same time was a bitch. Being in college is always different. I felt the need of finding that 25th hour of the day and worked day and night with so little sleep that I would snooze at least once a class.

item.title: Year 2: March
item.description: The Technical side I have a huge project in the works with Ryan and James. I hope it will be out on arxiv before I head off to NYC on May 14th. It’s so exciting that I am spending a lot of time in Lab making sure I get measurements in and getting clean data. The computational projects using DFT or my readings have been pushed out of the way to get this project through.

item.title: Year 2: February
item.description: February was quite a wild ride. The Technical side I really learned a ton of things here: In January, I focused on preparing samples for transport measurements while in February, I (re) learned how to do all the experiments I did in the past: Magnetization, transport (on a rotator), heat capacity, and even PXRD. Remembering the basics and how each one fits into a puzzle helped me figure out what I was looking for.

item.title: Year 2: January
item.description: And we’re back! Came back from almost a month break during which I played Taiko in LA, went to Ohio, and got covid… so no science. Popped back in and hit the ground running pushing projects and getting used to doing research full time. It feels great being able to accomplish and read things but it feels as if I run around all day making things happen and have one hour of concentrated work a day.

item.title: Year 2: November
item.description: I felt like I really got some momentum back in my research. A little late but a few highlights: Restarted DFT calculations and getting into computational condensed matter Started a Topological Order Reading Group with Kai and other friends in my year Got to know my mentors and got closer to other research group members. Decided to stick with James for my Phd Finished up being a TA for Physics 141A: Solid State physics with Joe Orenstein

item.title: Year 2: October
Year 2: September
item.description: Academically This month, I spent my time doing a rotation with Mike Zaletel. I looked into Density Matrix Renormalization Group (DMRG) method and topological order in the fractional quantum hall effect. I started to see how computationally nice one dimensional models are, how computationally hard two dimensional models are, and how hard three dimensions is. It fills me with a little sadness to know how hard it is to model three dimensional models.

item.title: Looking Back on the 1st Year of my PhD
item.description: Alas we are finished! The first year of the PhD is finished and I am happy. Happy for it to be over. Happy for it to have happened. Many things have occurred in the past year that have made itâ€¦. interesting. Unprecedented, you might say. I took Zoom classes and stayed indoor for the majority of the first half of the year. item.title: Year 1: February
item.description: Some new things happened this week. I got permissions to start work at LBNL and on campus. My became aware of the fantastic world of fractons, finally figured out what Tomonaga Luttinger liqudis were, and became more familiar with the Kitaev model. I’ve found myself getting more and more interested in 2D materials and finding out the connection between quantum spin liquids and other strongly correlated systems like unconventional superconductors. I am interested in how abelian/non-abelian anyons may come out of kitaev spin liquids and how they are related to the fact that the QSL must be described by a Conformal Field Theory with central charge c<1/2.

item.title: Year 1: Winterbreak
item.description: With COVID, I didn’t go home for the winter break. But I wasn’t sad. I got the Graduate Remote Instructor Fellowship to study different ways of planning for the (hopefully last) remote semester. I got to seemy partner a lot and explored Berkeley as much as we could. I even got work on my Taiko. It was nice. Living alone Once my suite mate left for home in late November for the Thanksgiving holidays, I was by myself!

item.title: First Semester: Fall 2020
item.description: Hello folks! Welcome to the first posting in my PhD blog. I hope to continue this throughout my five year journey. This last year has been an ordeal. I had graduated Columbia at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic taking my commencement ceremony sitting on my couch at home. We took the 2-3 hours to listen to the commencement ceremony and that was it: the ending of my undergraduate career. It felt a bit empty but it was that way for everyone.
